metadata.title: Copper Oxide Nanomaterials Derived from Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium Royle Plant Species: Characterization, Assessment of Free Radical Scavenging and Antibacterial Activity

sections.text:
Copper Oxide Nanomaterials Derived from Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE Plant Species: Characterization, Assessment of Free Radical Scavenging and Antibacterial Activity Azar Ullah Mirza,a Mohd Shoeb Khan,b Shahab A. A. Nami,c Abdul Kareem,a Sumbul Rehman,d
Shahnawaz Ahmad Bhat,a and Nahid Nishat*a
a Materials Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi 110025, India, e-mail: nishat_nchem08@yahoo.com
b Interdisciplinary Nanotechnology Center, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh 202002, India c Department of Kulliyat, Faculty of Unani Medicine, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh 202002, India
d Department of Ilmul Advia, Faculty of Unani Medicine, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh 202002, India
Copper oxide nanomaterials were synthesized by a facile sustainable biological method using two plant species (Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE). The formation of materials was confirmed by FT-IR, ATR, UV-visible, XRD, TEM, SEM, EDX, TGA and PL. The antibacterial activity was evaluated by agar well diffusion method to ascertain the efficacy of plant species extract and extract derived copper oxide nanomaterials against six Gram-positive bacteria namely Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus mutans, Streptococcus pyogenes, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Corynebacterium xerosis, Bacillus cereus and four Gram-negative bacteria such as Klebsiella pneumonia, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Proteus vulgaris against the standard drug, Ciprofloxacin for Gram-positive and Gentamicin for Gram-negative bacteria, respectively. In both cases, copper oxide nanomaterials were found to be sensitive in all the bacterial species. Sensitivity of copper oxide nanomaterials shows an be higher as compared to plant species extract against different bacteria. Scavenging activity of plant extracts along with nanomaterials have been accessed using previously reported protocols employing ascorbic acid as standard. Scavenging activity of copper oxide nanomaterials shows an increase with increase in concentration. The biological activity (bactericidal and scavenging efficiency) of plant derived copper oxide nanomaterials revealed that these materials can be used as potent antimicrobial agent and DPPH scavengers in industrial as well as pharmacological fields.
Keywords: copper oxide nanomaterials, plant extract, sustainable method, free radical scavenging, antibacterial activity, biological activity.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Latest area of research in the field of nanoscience is the development of nanomaterials of desired shape and size as these are determinantal in deciding their overall properties.[1,2] A number of methods are available for the synthesis of metal nanomaterials such as physical, chemical and biological. Among these approaches biological method is one of the most suitable methods for the fabrication of benign nanomaterials since it reduces the usage or production of hazardous materials to environment and human health. Bioinspired synthesis of metal based nanomaterials utilizes microorganisms such as fungi, bacteria and yeast.[3,4] Plant derived nanomaterials synthesis is an attractive method because of its facile, cost effective, and scalable approach. Plant species extract plays a significant role in the reduction, stabilization of nanomaterials and act as a capping and reducing agents.[5] Copper oxide is an important p-type semiconductor of metal oxide having a narrow band gap (1.2 eV). It plays cardinal role in antimicrobial drugs, solar cells, lithium ion battery, catalysis and gas sensor, etc. Copper oxide nanomaterials are stable, robust and
DOI: 10.1002/cbdv.201900145 FULL PAPER
Chem. Biodiversity 2019, 16, e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
have long shelf life as compared to organic and several inorganic materials.[6–9]
On the other hand medicinal plants are used for healing and curing of human diseases from time immemorial due to the presence of variety of phytochemicals.[10] Zanthoxylum armatum DC. is a glabrous tree with strong aromatic and pungent smell. Its local name is timbar or timar. It belongs to Rutaceae family and is used for its medicinal value in the south-Eastern Asia and Khasi tribe in north East regions of India. In India it occurs from warmer valleys of Himalaya (Jammu and Kashmir to Khasi) to eastern (Andra Pradesh and Orissa) and northeastern part of India (Manipur, Mizoram, Meghalaya and Naga Hills). It is used to control hyperglycemia, as antihelmintic, antipyretic, diseases related to teeth and mouth, for treatment of cholera, skin diseases and also has antimicrobial, antifungal, antitumor, analgesic, anti-inflammatory, insecticidal/larvicidal and antioxidant activities.[11–14] Similarly, Berberis lycium ROYLE has worldwide distribution all over the world mainly in India, east Africa, North America, South America, Pakistan, west and central Asia, south-east Asia, China and Japan. It belongs to Berberidaceae family and has ever green shrubs, deciduous, spiny, characteristic flowers and yellow wood. This plant has many medicinal applications and pharmacological activities due to the presence of alkaloids. The leaves of this plant are used as a substitute for tea and used for the treatment of jaundice.[15–17] The main constituents of Zanthoxylum armatum plant species includes the phytochemicals such as saponins, alkaloids, coumarins, sterols, lignans, terpenes, phenolic compounds and flavenoids.[18–23] On the other hand Berberis lycium ROYLE plant species contains many terpenoids, alkaloids, polyphenolics, flavenoids, sterols, anthocyanins, lignans, proteins, carotenoids, vitamins and lipids. Sterols, stigmasterol can be obtained from hexane extract while stigmasterol glycoside from ethyl acetate extract. Alkaloids include berberamine and palmatine. Some other important alkaloids such as columbamine, isocorydine, oxyberberine, magniflorine and bisbenzylisoquinolines (oxycanthine)[24,25] have also been isolated. Although the biosynthesis of copper oxide nanomaterials by plant extracts such as chamomile flower extract,[26] Ficus religiosa,[27] Sida acuta,[28] Populus ciliata,[29] tragacanth gel,[30] Aloe vera extract[31] have been reported, the potential of plant extracts as biomaterials for the synthesis of nanomaterials is yet to be explored. The objective of the present study is to synthesize copper oxide nanomaterials derived from plant species extracts (Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE). The morphology of plants leaf is shown in Figure 1a and b. The characterization of synthesized materials was carried out by UV-visible, ATR, FT-IR, XRD, SEM, EDX, TEM, TGA and PL. Biological evaluation of plant extracts and copper oxide nanomaterials were comparatively been carried out. The antibacterial activity against different bacterial strains and antioxidant activity by DPPH assay using copper oxide nanomaterials derived from the two different plant species were also studied.

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Visual/UV-Visible Observations The reduction action of plant extracts (Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE) on copper acetate solution for the formation of plant derived copper oxide nanomaterials is indicated by the changes in color in the reaction mixture. The absorption spectra of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. plant extract showed peaks at 225 and 235 nm while its copper oxide nanomaterials exhibited bands at 255, 267 and 270 nm, respectively. Similarly, Berberis lycium ROYLE plant extract showed the bands at 244, 276, 290 and 297 nm and its mediated copper oxide nanomaterials at 204 and 273 nm, respectively, and are given in Figures 2 and 3.[31–33] ATR Spectra Figure 4a and b represents phytoextract of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE. In Zanthoxylum armatum DC., the peaks observed at 3287 and 3240 cm 1 are due to OH stretching of phenol indicating the presence of polyphenol, whereas the peak appeared at 2983 cm 1 is ascribed to C=O group of carboxylic acid. The bands observed at 1396 and 1316 cm 1 are due to CH3 of alkane group while the peak at 1261 cm 1 is due to stretching vibration of ester group. The band at 1641 cm 1 may be ascribed to C=O stretching of amide. Similarly, the peaks at 688, 661 and 614 cm 1 may be assigned to C H bending of aromatic moiety. On the other hand, in the case of Berberis lycium ROYLE, the bands appeared at 3307 and 3246 cm 1 are due to stretching of phenolic group (OH stretching), whereas the peak observed at 2962 cm 1 is assignable to C=O group of carboxylic
www.cb.wiley.com (2 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
acid. The band observed at 1343 cm 1 may be attributed to the CH3 of alkane group. The stretching bands at 1262 and 1734 cm 1 is due to C O C and C=O stretching vibration of ester group. Peak observed at 1640 cm 1 is attributed to C=O stretching of amide group. Moreover, the appearance of peak at 695, 607 and 606 cm 1 is due to C H bending vibrations of aromatic ring.[34,35] FT-IR Analysis
The bands at 3271 and 3460 cm 1 are ascribed to the hydroxy groups of phenolic and alcoholic moieties. The peak observed at 1342 cm 1 is due to deforming vibration of C H band of alkane (CH3 and CH2) group, while the bands observed at 787 and 916 cm 1 are attributed to C H group bending of aromatic moiety. The band at 1660 cm 1 is due to aromatic bending of alkene (C=C) group, while the bands at 651 and 496 cm 1 are due to the vibrational modes of Berberis
www.cb.wiley.com (3 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
lycium ROYLE derived copper oxide nanomaterial. In the case of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. derived copper oxide nanomaterial the bands observed at 3318 and 3433 cm 1 may be attributed to hydroxy groups of alcoholic and phenolic moieties. The band observed at 1355 cm 1 is due to deforming vibration of C H bond of alkane (CH3 and CH2 group). Similarly, the peaks observed at 767, 882 and 990 cm 1 are due to aromatic bending of C H group, while the peak at 1626 cm 1 is due to the bending of alkene (aromatic C=C) group. However, the bands observed at 639, 564 and 455 cm 1 confirm clearly the formation of copper oxide nanomaterial using plant species extract (Figure 5a and b).[36,37]
X-RD Pattern
The XRD pattern of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. mediated copper oxide nanomaterial is shown in Figure 6a. The XRD pattern with 2θ values are equal to 35.39°, 38.51°, 48.89°, 52.15° and 60.75° corresponding to (002), (111), (202), (020) and (113) planes. The synthesized copper oxide nanomaterial is crystalline in nature. In the case of Berberis lycium ROYLE copper oxide nanomaterial, the peaks were observed with 2θ at 35.98°, 38.51°, 48.74°, 52.44°, 56.60°, 60.75° and 65.65° and indexed at (002), (111), (202), (020), (202), (113) and (311) implying high crystallinity is given in Figure 6b. In both cases, the results are in accordance with the international pattern of diffraction data number (JPCDS-05-0661). The size of materials can be calculated by using Debye Scherrer formula as follows:
D ¼ kl=b cosq
where D is the average particle size, k is the shape factor (approximately equal to 0.9), λ is the X-ray wavelength, β is the full width half wave maximum (FWHM) of the biosynthesized nanomaterials powder (1.5406 Å CuKα) and θ is the Bragg’s angle. The average size of both copper oxide nanomaterials was found to be 48.42 and 54.13 nm.[38,39]
Figure 5. FT-IR spectra of a) Zanthoxylum armatum DC. b) Berberis lycium ROYLE assisted copper oxide nanomaterials.
www.cb.wiley.com (4 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
SEM Analysis
The SEM image of biosynthesized copper oxide nanomaterials using Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE are well dispersed, nanosize and crystalline in nature are given in Figure 7a and b. The morphology, surface of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. mediated nanomaterial is rough, some particles are hexagonal, cylindrical and a lump of more agglomerated nanoparticles because of presence of several
www.cb.wiley.com (5 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
aggregates. On other hand in the case of Berberis lycium ROYLE derived copper oxide nanomaterial, morphology is rough, cluster like, less aggregation as compared to the previous one, and some crystals are also observed to have spherical in shape. EDX Analysis
The compositional and confirmation analysis of biosynthesized copper oxide nanomaterials are presented in Figure 8a and b. In copper oxide nanomaterial derived from Zanthoxylum armatum DC, the elemental percentage of copper and oxygen are given in Table 1, whereas in the case of Berberis lycium ROYLE, the percentage of copper and oxygen is presented in Table 2. The spectrum shows a strong signal for copper content and small signal for oxygen confirming the formation of copper oxide nanomaterial in both cases. There is no extra peak in the EDX spectrum.
Table 1. Elemental composition of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. derived copper oxide nanomaterial.
Element Weight [%] Atomic [%]
OK 20.28 50.25 Cu K 79.72 49.75 Total 100.00 100.00
www.cb.wiley.com (6 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
TEM Analysis
Transmission electron micrograph of copper oxide nanomaterial clearly depicts rodlike and cylindrical appearances prepared from two different plant species, respectively. The TEM images were recorded at X43000 magnification. The particle size distribution were analyzed using the software ‘ImageJ’ for both the ecofriendly prepared copper oxide nanomaterials and the histogram is given in Figure 9a and b. The particle size of copper oxide nanomaterials were observed in the range of 40–58.05 nm and 44–58 nm, respectively. Average size of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. mediated copper oxide nanomaterial is 43 nm while for Berberis lycium ROYLE derived copper oxide nanomaterial is 45 nm. These findings are consistent with the XRD results.
Thermal Behavior
The thermal behavior was studied by thermogravimetric analysis. The thermal study of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE derived copper oxide nanomaterial was carried out under nitrogen atmosphere. The initial weight loss is attributed to the loss of adsorbed water molecules. Substantial weight loss ranges from 200 to 410 °C is ascribed to the degradation of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. derived copper oxide nanomaterial and it remains constant up to 600 °C. Similarly, a weight loss ranging from 150 to 400 °C corresponds to the combustion of Berberis lycium ROYLE plant derived copper oxide material, remains invariable up to 600 °C and is shown in Figure 10a and b.[40,41]
Photoluminescence Spectra
Figure 11a shows the photoluminescence spectrum of copper oxide nanomaterial derived from Berberis lycium ROYLE plant extract. The emission band at 415 nm is a large blue violet luminescent shoulder band, typically a near edge-band emission of copper oxide nanomaterial. The shoulder band occurring at 435 nm is a blue emission due to the copper vacancies in copper oxide which is a p-type semiconductor.[42] At low temperature, the emission peak is observed at 532 nm due to deep level effects.[43] The copper oxide ultraviolet emission appears due to the recombination of electron hole pair in free excitations.[32] A small band at 555 nm is due to green emission arises from single ionization of oxygen vacancy. The photoluminescence spectra of copper oxide nanomaterial using
Zanthoxylum armatum DC. plant extract is shown in Figure 11b. A visible emission band is observed at 403 nm. The emission peak at 417 nm is a large blue violet luminescent shoulder band which is a near edge-band emission of copper oxide nanomaterial. The shoulder band occurring at 445 nm is a blue emission because of copper vacancies in copper oxide which is again a p-type semiconductor.[44] The emission peak observed at 531 nm is due to deep level effects. This type of defect generally occurs at low temperatures.[45] The copper oxide ultraviolet emission is due to recombination of electron hole pair in free excitations.[46] A small hump at 555 nm is due to green emission obtained from single ionization of oxygen vacancy.
Antibacterial Activity
The antibacterial activity of copper oxide nanomaterials against different bacterial strains is given in Figures 12, 13 and Table 3. The microorganisms bearing negative charge and nanomaterials having positive charge produce an interaction between the organisms and nanomaterials. The interaction of bacterial membrane with copper oxide nanomaterials is because of nanosized and extremely large surface area which provides better contact with the organisms. Release of copper ions and their successive binding with DNA molecules lead to the disorder in structure by crosslinking between the nucleic acids. Bacterial cell also disrupts the biochemical processes due to copper ions inside the cells. The bactericidal activity is dependent upon the penetration of copper oxide nanomaterial through the bacterial cell membrane cause damage in membrane resulting in cell death. The nanosize bioderived copper oxide nanomaterials are more sensitive than the larger size nanomaterials.[47 – 49] In Zanthoxylum armatum DC. (JD), the three resistant species against Gram-positive bacteria are Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus and Corynebacterium xerosis while the three sensitive bacteria are Streptococcus mutans, Staphylococcus pyogenes and Staphylococcus epidermidis. The highest inhibition zone is in the case
www.cb.wiley.com (7 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
of Streptococcus mutans, a Gram-positive bacterium, while in Gram-negative bacteria, the highest inhibition zone is in the case of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The copper oxide nanomaterial derived from Zanthoxylum armatum DC. species (CJ), both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria are sensitive. In Gram-positive, the highest inhibition zone is in the case of Streptococcus mutans, Staphylococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus epidermidis and lowest inhibition zone in Corynebacterium xerosis. In Gram-negative bacteria, the
www.cb.wiley.com (8 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
highest inhibition zone is in the case of Klebsiella pneumonia and lowest inhibition zone is in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. In Berberis lycium ROYLE (SU), Grampositive bacteria (Streptococcus mutans and Staphylococcus epidermidis) is sensitive, but the other bacterial strains (Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus pyogenes, Bacillus cereus and Corynebacterium xerosis) is resistant, whereas in the case of Gram-negative bacteria, only Pseudomonas aeruginosa are sensitive while the other bacterial species are resistant (Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumonia and Proteus vulgaris). The highest inhibition zone in Streptococcus mutans, a Gram-positive bacteria, while in Gram-negative bacteria, the highest inhibition zone is in the case of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Berberis lycium ROYLE assisted copper oxide nanomaterial (UM) is sensitive against the Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacterial strains. The highest zone of inhibition is in Gram-positive (Streptococcus Mutans) and lowest in (Staphylococcus pyogenes and Corynebacterium xerosis) whereas in the case of Gram-negative bacteria, the highest zone of inhibition in Escherichia coli and lowest in Klebsiella pneumonia.[50–56] Free Radical Scavenging Activity Antioxidant activity of aqueous plant extract and copper oxide nanomaterials using plant extract were investigated, copper oxide nanomaterials are found to be more effective antioxidant agents as compared to the plant extract in both system. The results are presented in Table 4 and Figure 14. The dose dependence scavenging potential of plant extract and copper oxide nanomaterials shows an increase with increase in concentration. Berberis lycium ROYLE (SU) and its derived copper oxide nanomaterial (UM) are more active as compared to the Zanthoxylum armatum DC.
www.cb.wiley.com (9 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
(JD) and its synthesized copper oxide nanomaterial (CJ) in accordance with the standard (L-ascorbic acid). The enhancement of antioxidant abilities of copper oxide can be attributed due to the presence of phytochemicals of plant extract in the nanomaterials as a capping agents. In presence of DPPH, copper oxide nanomaterials have a capacity to transfer an electron density towards the free radical located on nitrogen atom.[57–60]

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In the present study, the synthesis of derived copper oxide nanomaterials using Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE plant leaf extract via biological route is done. The materials were characterized by various analytical techniques such as UV-visible, FTIR, ATR, XRD, SEM, EDX, TEM, TGA and PL which shows good performance in biological applications. From the antibacterial activity, it is found that the Berberis lycium ROYLE assisted copper oxide nanomaterial is more active against some bacterial strains in comparison to the Zanthoxylum armatum DC. copper oxide nanomaterial. Copper oxide nanomaterials are sensitive in all bacterial strains as compared to plant extracts. The scavenging activity of plant extracts and plant extracts derived nanomaterials using L-ascorbic acid as a standard reference were also carried out. The antioxidant power increases with increase in concentration of phytoextract and copper oxide nanomaterials. Thus, we propose a new biomediated protocol to synthesize copper oxide nanomaterials through an ecofriendly, cost-effective, facile route to obtain high purity, crystalline, small size and self assembled nanomaterials, which may be useful for various biological, biomedical and environmental applications.
www.cb.wiley.com (10 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland

sections.heading: Experimental Section
sections.text:
Materials and Methods
Copper(II) acetate monohydrate, sodium hydroxide, ethanol, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and sulfuric acid were obtained from Merck. 2,2-Diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl free radical (DPPH) from Alfa Aesar and methanol was supplied by Finar. Zanthoxylum armatum DC. (Rutaceae) and
Berberis lycium ROYLE (Berberidaceae) were collected from a village Bhattian, Thanamandi, Rajouri, Jammu and Kashmir, India. Glasswares were washed with chromic acid, double distilled water, finally rinsed with ethanol and acetone. All the chemicals, solvents were of analytical grade and used as received. Deionized water is used throughout the synthesis.
Medium and Microorganisms for Test
The solid media was Nutrient Agar No.2 (M 1269S500G, Himedia Labs Pvt., Ltd., Bombay, India) was used for preparation of nutrient plates, while the other is Nutrient Broth (M002-500G, Himedia Labs Pvt., Ltd., Bombay, India) was used for preparing liquid culture media. On the basis of their clinical use in creating diseases in humans, some clinical isolation of Grampositive and Gram-negative bacterial strains were selected. The strains were procured from Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College and Hospital, Department of Microbiology, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh. Bacterial strains chosen for the study such as Grampositive bacteria were Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus), Streptococcus mutans (S. mutans), Streptococcus pyogenes (S. pyogenes), Staphylococcus epidermidis (S. epidermidis), Bacillus cereus (B. cereus), Corynebacterium xerosis (C. xerosis) and Gram-negative bacterial strains were Escherichia coli (E. coli), Klebsiella pneumonia (K. pneumonia), Pseudomonas aeruginosa (P. aeruginosa) and Proteus vulgaris (P. vulgaris). These microbial strains were screened for the determination of antibacterial activities of the plant extract and its synthesized nanomaterials.
Preparation of Plant Extracts
The collected plant leaves (Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and Berberis lycium ROYLE) were washed many times in running tap water and finally with double distilled water until no debris remained. The leaves were dried at room temperature under shady condition. About 20 g of plant leaves were chopped, grinded with mortar-pestle, transferred into 250 ml conical flask containing 100 ml of water and heated for 1 h at 70 °C using magnetic stirrer. The obtained extract was filtered and used for the synthesis of nanomaterials.
Biosynthesis of Copper Oxide Nanomaterials
In an aqueous solution of copper acetate (20 mM in 80 ml water), 20 ml plant extract was added dropwise in 250 ml conical flask. The solution was stirred at 90°C for
www.cb.wiley.com (11 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
5 min. The pH of the solution was maintained at 10 using 0.1 M NaOH or 0.1 N HCl and stirred for 1 h using magnetic stirrer. The change in color from blue green to black in the case of Zanthoxylum armatum DC. and light brown in the case of Berberis lycium ROYLE was observed. The solution is centrifuged at 8,000 rpm for 20 min. The materials were collected, washed with double distilled water, finally with acetone and were allowed to dry on a watch glass in an oven at 100°C for 4 h. The precipitates so formed were used for further analysis.

www.cb.wiley.com (12 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
Mechanism
The mechanism is depicted in Scheme 1 and is explained by using the polyphenolic content in the leaf extract of plant species. The phenolic constituents have high reducing potential and facilitate the reduction of Cu2+ ions into CuO nanomaterials. The polyphenolic compound undergoes oxidation from phenolic form which results in reduction of Cu2+ ions into CuO.[61,62]
Instrumentations
Ultraviolet-Visible Absorption
The UV-visible absorption spectra were recorded at room temperature at 200–800 nm range in a quartz cuvette with scan rate of 600 nm/min using deionized water as a solvent on a Hitachi, U3900 UV-visible spectrometer.
Attenuated Total Reflectance
The ATR analysis was done on Tensor 37 spectrophotometer, Germany using Opus-150 spectroscopic software ranging from 4000 to 600 cm 1.
Fourier Transform Infrared
The FT-IR characterization was performed by using KBr pellet on a Bruker Tensor-37 spectrometer, Germany, at 4000–400 cm 1.
X-Ray Diffraction
The XRD analysis were done by using X-ray diffractometer, Ultima IV model, Rigaku cooperation, Japan, operating at 40 kV with Nickel filtered CuKα (k 51.54 Å), 2θ ranging from 10° to 80° with a scan rate of 1° min 1.
Scanning Electron Microscopy
The morphology of copper oxide nanomaterials derived from plant species extract were studied at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV using a JSM-6510, SEM Version 1.0.
Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy
A SEM attached EDX instrument was used for the confirmation and determination of elemental composition of plant derived copper oxide nanomaterials.
Transmission Electron Microscopy
TEM were used to ascertain the morphology and size of the copper oxide nanomaterials by FEI-Technai operating at a voltage of 200 kV.
Thermal Analysis
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out under nitrogen atmosphere for the determination of weight changes of copper oxide nanomaterials. Temperature ranging from 10 to 600 °C at heating rate of 10 °C/min and gas flow rate was 50 ml/min.
Photoluminescence Studies
Photoluminescence analysis of copper oxide nanomaterials was carried out by using Agilent Technologies (Eclipse, Fluorescence spectrophotometer) based on excitation emission in the range of 400–600 nm at room temperature taking distilled water as a solvent.
Antibacterial Assay
The antibacterial activity was evaluated by agar well diffusion method. The microbial cultures were adjusted to 0.5 McFarland standards, which is comparable to a microbial suspension of 1.5×108 cfu/ml. Agar media (20 ml) was added into each Petri plate and plates were swabbed with a colony from the inoculums of the test microorganisms and kept at 15 min for adsorption. Using 6 mm diameter sterile cork borer, wells were bored into the seeded agar plates and these were loaded with a 100 μl of test sample remake in DMSO. Sample plates were incubated for 24 h at 37 °C.
Antibacterial activity was determined by measuring the zone of growth inhibition against the test
Scheme 1. Proposed mechanism of synthesized copper oxide nanomaterials.
www.cb.wiley.com (13 of 16) e1900145 © 2019 Wiley-VHCA AG, Zurich, Switzerland
organisms with antibiotic zone scale (PW297, Himedia Labs Pvt., Ltd., Mumbai, India), which was held on the back of the plate. The plate was carried few inches above a nonreflecting background, blackish and illuminated with reflected light. The medium with DMSO as solvent was used as a negative control whereas media with standard antibiotic for Grampositive 5 μg/disk (Ciprofloxacin) and 10 μg/disk standard antibiotic for Gram-negative (Gentamicin) were used as positive control. The measurements were performed in triplicate.
Free Radical Scavenging Activity
The scavenging activity was measured by using 2,2- diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl free radical.[18] DPPH was used as the radical source and copper oxide was used as free radical scavenger. DPPH radical has a deep violet color in solution and gradually it becomes colorless or pale yellow in the presence of copper oxide nanomaterials. Copper oxide nanomaterials and plant extracts were stirred using magnetic stirrer and placed for 40 min at 35 °C in dark condition. The reduction action of radical was determined by using UV-visible spectrophotometer and absorbance was recorded at 517 nm. Free radical scavenging percentage is calculated using the following equation:
% DDPH scavenging ¼ ½AA AB�
AA � 100
where, AA is absorbance of blank, AB is the absorbance of test samples.

Shoeb Khan, Dr. Abdul Kareem, Dr. Shahab A. A. Nami, Dr. Sumbul Rehman and Shahnawaz Ahmad Bhat under the extreme guidance of Prof. Nahid Nishat.
